close_symbols: MHD_Result enum and MHD_YES / MHD_NO definitions
explanation:
- struct UserEntry (full definition): needed to know the types and qualifiers of the fields (username, realm and the userhash/userdigest buffers). This clarifies whether assigning entry->username = username or entry->realm = realm writes through the pointer or simply copies the pointer value, and whether any const-qualification mismatch exists.
- user_ids (declaration/definition): needed to confirm the type (array of struct UserEntry) and storage so that entry = user_ids + user_ids_used and the subsequent assignment target are correctly interpreted (i.e. that we are assigning into a struct member, not into a parameter).
- user_ids_used (declaration): needed to confirm it is a global/static variable (not a parameter) and its type/limits to ensure the index arithmetic and increment do not involve or modify any function parameter.
- MHD_digest_auth_calc_userhash (prototype): needed to see the parameter types/qualifiers (e.g. whether it accepts const char * or modifies passed pointers) so you can determine whether calling it could legally modify the objects pointed to or would require converting/violating qualifiers. This clarifies that called functions cannot alter the caller's parameter variables (only the pointed-to objects).
- MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest (prototype): same reason as for MHD_digest_auth_calc_userhash.
- MHD_Result enum and MHD_YES / MHD_NO definitions: needed to understand the type and values used in res comparisons/assignments to confirm control flow (which calls execute) and ensure no hidden side-effect through macros that could modify parameters.
